item.title: Covid: Matt Hancock faces MPs over Dominic Cummings' claims
item.description: The health secretary rejects the accusation that he lied to colleagues about his Covid handling.

item.title: Rising patient numbers threaten to overwhelm GPs
item.description: Patients are struggling to get appointments as GPs report a surge in appointments being booked.

item.title: Covid-19 vaccine booking opens for everyone over 18 in NI
item.description: There will be about 20,000 slots available to book weekly, says the Department of Health.

item.title: Fred West: No human remains found in Mary Bastholm search
item.description: Gloucestershire Police are excavating the cellar of The Clean Plate cafe in Gloucester.

item.title: County lines: 1,100 people arrested in UK crackdown
item.description: Eighty drug dealing phone lines were identified and 292 weapons seized across the UK in a week.

item.title: Covid: Biden orders investigation into virus origin as lab leak theory debated
item.description: US intelligence is divided on whether the virus came from a Chinese lab or animal-to-human contact.

item.title: Climate: World at risk of hitting temperature limit soon
item.description: It's increasingly likely that a key temperature limit will be reached in one of the next five years.

item.title: 'There's a sense black people are being paid less'
item.description: It's a year since businesses made racial diversity pledges following George Floyd’s death - so what has changed?

item.title: Brad Pitt awarded joint custody of children with Angelina Jolie
item.description: The actor has been granted joint custody of his children with Angelina Jolie after a court battle.

item.title: Marcus Rashford: Manchester United striker highlights racial abuse after Europa League loss
item.description: Manchester United forward Marcus Rashford says he has received "at least 70 racial slurs" on social media following the Europa League final loss to Villarreal.

item.title: North Yorkshire Police find nine people in uninsured car
item.description: Two female passengers crawled out of the boot during the traffic stop in North Yorkshire.

item.title: Friends reunion: 10 of the best moments
item.description: The six stars have reunited for a new televised special, 17 years after Friends drew to a close.

item.title: 'I pictured my son's drowning on my charity swim'
item.description: A woman, whose son drowned on holiday, tells how the open water challenge stirred up panic attacks and flashbacks.

item.title: Nexta: The journalists taking on Belarus’ regime
item.description: The BBC visits the colleagues of Roman Protasevich, the journalist arrested off the diverted Ryan Air flight.

item.title: The Papers: Cummings 'rains fire' with 'pure revenge'
item.description: The papers react to claims from Boris Johnson's former top aide about the handling of the pandemic.

item.title: Gogglebox Tom and girlfriend 'trolled' for BLM support
item.description: The Black Lives Matter protests impacted relationships within families and couples in the UK.

item.title: Stephen Hawking's papers to be saved for the nation
item.description: Prof Stephen Hawking's scientific papers and personal possessions to be saved for the nation.

item.title: Dominic Cummings: The seven most explosive claims
item.description: The PM's former chief aide makes a series of allegations about the government's Covid response.

item.title: GP practices in England facing 'tsunami of patients'
item.description: Dr Dean Eggitt, a GP in Doncaster, opened his doors to the BBC to show the pressures facing practices.

item.title: Flower tattoos heal self-harm scars
item.description: South Korean tattoo artist, Yeon, helps women cover up self-harm scars with images of flowers.

item.title: Tulsa massacre: The search for victims, 100 years on
item.description: Decades after white mobs razed an affluent black neighbourhood the search for bodies goes on.

item.title: Cummings' claims fact-checked
item.description: Boris Johnson's former chief adviser made a series of claims and allegations about the government's response to the pandemic.

item.title: Tokyo Olympic Games: When are they and will they go ahead?
item.description: The Tokyo Summer Olympics are due to start in July, despite a surge in Covid cases in Japan.

item.title: The uncertain future of Britain's offices
item.description: UK firms' offices are undergoing radical shifts as firms allow staff to continue working from home.

item.title: Coronavirus: What guidance did care homes get from the government?
item.description: Boris Johnson says "too many care homes didn't really follow the procedures", so what was the coronavirus guidance given to them?

item.title: Mozambique Palma attack: 'I had to pay a bribe to flee'
item.description: Aid agencies have been barred from parts of Mozambique, leading to fears of a humanitarian emergency.

item.title: 'Fortress Australia': Why calls to open up borders are meeting resistance
item.description: Many Australians are loath to relax border controls despite experts warning of the harms of isolation.

item.title: Luke Combs dissects his lockdown anthem Six Feet Apart, one year later
item.description: US country star Luke Combs wrote one of the first musical responses to Covid-19. How does it hold up?

item.title: RTHK: How authorities cracked down on Hong Kong's only public broadcaster
item.description: New changes in RTHK have signalled that its fate as an independent public service may be under threat.

item.title: New players? And what about Pogba? The major decisions facing Solskjaer
item.description: Manchester United boss Ole Gunnar Solskjaer has ambitions beyond a Europa League final, but has numerous issues to solve first.

item.title: Houghton, Weir and Ingle in GB squad for Olympics
item.description: England captain Steph Houghton is among those selected for the Team GB squad at this summer's Olympic Games.

item.title: Season without a trophy not a success - Solskjaer
item.description: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer accepts this season has not been a success for Manchester United but believes his squad has the right characters to do better next term.

item.title: Wizards' Westbrook wants action after popcorn incident with fan
item.description: The Washington Wizards guard Russell Westbrook had to be restrained by security after a fan poured popcorn over him in his side's 120-95 defeat at the Philadelphia 76ers.

item.title: The next English Bundesliga star? Bayern Munich sign Reading's Richards
item.description: Reading left-back Omar Richards is to join German Bundesliga champions Bayern Munich this summer on a four-year deal.

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being surge tested for variants?
item.description: People who live, work or travel in various parts of the UK are being urged to get a Covid test.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Over-18s can now have the vaccine in Wales and Northern Ireland, while over-30s can get it in England and Scotland.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Coronavirus: When can we stop wearing face masks or face coverings?
item.description: Rules are relaxing, but masks are still needed in some settings - here's where and why.

item.title: Coronavirus: What's the risk of Covid on public transport?
item.description: As UK coronavirus restrictions are relaxed, public transport could become much busier.

item.title: Covid vaccines: How fast is progress around the world?
item.description: Charts and maps tracking the progress of Covid vaccination programmes.

item.title: Children tell of neglect, filth and fear in US asylum camps
item.description: The BBC has uncovered allegations of cold temperatures, sickness, lice and abuse, through a series of interviews with children and staff at US detention camps for children.

item.title: Rafael Nadal: The 'tough love' that shaped a 20-time Grand Slam champion
item.description: From 'scaredy cat' to a 'raging bull', Rafael Nadal's transformation into a true tennis great has a lot to do with one man in particular.

item.title: Martin Bashir inquiry: Diana, the reporter and the BBC
item.description: The full story of how the BBC's Martin Bashir got his 1995 interview with Princess Diana - and what happened next.
